Award.AwardTitle: Spectral theory of ergodic Schrodinger operators and related models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research concerns the study of the fundamental properties of disordered systems. Disordered systems are models of systems with impurities. The development of a rigorous theory of disordered systems is expected to contribute to the understanding of many types of physical phenomena, and in particular, may lead to finding new materials with desired physical properties. Disordered systems are also used in modeling many other micro and macro effects from quantum localization- an important topic in quantum computation- to earthquakes. An integral part of the project concerns educating graduate students and other young researchers. The PI will also continue her outreach efforts to entice K-12 students to the study of mathematics.


The project consists of several parts. One is to prove the extended states for multidimensional quasiperiodic operators. Another is to study the effects of interaction in tight-binding quasi-periodic models. One more is to study local eigenvalue statistics in the regime of localization for discrete ergodic Schroedinger operators. It is also planned to study several models related to Bloch electrons in constant magnetic fields, notably the Extended Harper Model. Other important objectives are the study of issues related to Cantor/non-Cantor spectra of quasiperiodic operators. The project involves the continuing development of non-perturbative methods for the proofs of localization type effects both in Schrodinger operators and in quantum spin systems, percolation and contact processes in disordered environments, as well as for the study of absolutely continuous spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project consists in solving several open
problems in analysis motivated by questions in solid state physics and in
development of corresponding theories. Our work has been mostly related to sharp transitions in spectral theory, with some work related to geometry and number theory. My results on quasiperiodic operators included discovery of the universal structure of eigenfunctions throughout the pure point region, with arithmetical hierarchy in the regimes of both frequency and phase resonances,  sharp arithmetic transitions between point and singular continuous spectrum,  proof of the arithmetic spectral transition conjectures for both phase and frequency, sharp arithmetic criterion for full dimensionality of the spectral measure for general analytic operators, first and/or strongest results for critical Harper and extended Harper, sharp topological criteria for relation between reducibility and dual localization , first class of bounded potentials with all-coupling localization , first arithmetic results for shifts and skew-shifts of higher-dimensional tori, rst results for general dynamics of zero topological entropy or rough potentials without parameter exclusion, first study of Lyapunov-Perron non-regular points in a natural setting, the development of tools to prove spectral continuity [8], leading to natural examples with dierent Hausdorff and packing dimension and other unusual phenomena. The results on multidimensional quasiperiodic operators include proof of Anderson localization for any dimension of the underlying torus and genericity of continuous spectrum. The results on periodic/magnetic models include the first and at the same time full study of spectral properties of quantum graph graphene in constant magnetic field and proof of discrete Bethe-Sommerfeld conjecture in any dimension. The results on noncompact Riemannian manifolds include the first construction of manifolds, in any dimension with dense point spectrum embedded in the ac spectrum of Laplace-Beltrami operator and sharp curvature criteria for the possibility of such embedding. Results in number theory include solution of Erd}os-Szekeres problem and resolution of two conjectures in co-prime approximation.

 Our focus has been both on developing new methods and theories in this branch of analysis/dynamical systems and on applications to models that are of interest to the physics community. As such, we obtained new results and proved open conjectures on the quantum graph model of graphene in a magnetic eld, almost Mathieu, Maryland, and extended Harper's operators. In particular, our results on the extended Harper's model resolved a controversy in Physics literature.

The project contributed to the training of six postdoctoral fellows and eleven
graduate students.
